item.title: starting on Wayland development
item.author: Author
item.description: Do you wanna contribute to a funky open-source project? Are you tired of your nerdy and boring community of developers? Are you the one that wants to get rid of X because it’s a giant, old and fat dinosaur in your system? :) Cool, I have a project to solve your problems! While there’s still lot of churn in the protocol, and yet our goal is soon to wrap up all we’ve been doing to a steady and settle-on-the-stone one description, there’s a lot on the implementation side that needs love.

item.title: X Census (for 1.9)
item.author: Author
item.description: Topic’s name is a funny (and friendly) devotion to GNOME Census. So let’s take a look at some numbers from the time Xorg 1.9 was in development - raw data is here. Would be unfair to measure only the work that happened e.g. in X server or in the drivers being developed and come up with the statistics about “who developed X”. X and X development community are quite extensive and don’t concern only “graphics” related, i.

item.title: Attracting reviewers in your patch series
item.author: Author
item.description: Usually faster the number of commits, faster the development process. But development without strict reviewing doesn’t guarantee quality on the code. Unfortunately, rarely you will see people willing or even just being able to review the changes you are proposing. Attract reviewers is hard! Lemma: The art of writing a good patch series is all about to attract reviewers. Proof is omitted due to lack of space. Sorry ;) I’d start to write a post about how to write a nice commit message and patch series, so I could use as a future reference for you.
